Was that slow enough Nick?

I worry I&#39;ve been doing too much weeb shit 
lately. Tends to draw a certain crowd. Hey,

if you like sputtering one out to greasy cartoon 
tits that jiggle like semi-sentient party balloons

then more power to you, just seems weird to get 
so evangelical about it. Anime fans are like

vegans without the moral superiority or the - no 
actually, about the same body odour. &quot;Ooh Yahtzee

if you liked Ys 9 so much you should try Wonderful 
Party Balloon Romance Panic IV as well!&quot; Oh god,

you&#39;re all so fucking greasy you&#39;re turning my 
front lawn into Sauerkraut just by standing on it.

Look, anime is like an ice cream parlour. It&#39;s a 
fun treat now and again but if you go there every

day you&#39;ll end up fat and disgusting and being 
used as a cautionary example for the benefit of

the small children with whom you share a hobby. 
And its variety of flavours and hair colours all

kinda taste the same when buried under a pile of 
gummi bears and blatant fetishisation. And when I

go there I usually stick to the low fat yoghurt 
option because it&#39;s only ever the exceptions

that I seem to like. So don&#39;t go filling the 
comments with visual novel recommendations

just &#39;cos I&#39;m doing a visual novel, now, I 
only like the Ace Attorney games because of

the ways they differ from most visual novels.
In that there&#39;s actual gameplay that it&#39;s possible

to lose and puzzles you have to think about 
and you&#39;re not just hammering the skip dialog

button with one hand and rubbing your little 
hairy chapstick with the other. And with that

masterful setting of tone, we press on. Ace 
Attorney is a long running series of wholesome

courtroom adventures about finding just enough of 
a hole in the seemingly watertight prosecution to

cram in the destructive dildo of defense and 
blow the case apart. But they&#39;ve always had

the same problem pre-Like A Dragon Yakuza games 
had in that you only really need to play one of

them. Little details change but the broad strokes 
are always the same - you&#39;re a wide-eyed young

lawyer who&#39;s clumsy and innocent but with a good 
heart and faith in humanity who spends a slightly

untoward amount of time around underage girls, and 
you&#39;re up against a higher-status prosecutor who&#39;s

way overconfident for someone with no clearer 
idea of how legal systems actually work than

anyone else in the plot. And the only strategy 
the developers have ever had for mixing up the

formula is to swap out the main characters for 
new ones who are precisely the fucking same.

Hence The Great Ace Attorney Adventures, an 
only recently officially translated prequel

to Ace Attorney starring Phoenix Wright&#39;s Japanese 
ancestor at the dawn of the 20th century. Now why

would Phoenix Wright have a Japanese ancestor? 
Cough. Surely the Phoenix Wright games all take

place in America? Cough cough, droll look 
to camera. Ryunosuke Naruhodo - no I will

not attempt a Japanese accent - is a wide-eyed 
clumsy innocent good-hearted law student who&#39;s

forced to defend himself against a murder 
charge and through a contrived series of

events ends up travelling to Victorian London on 
a cultural exchange, befriending several underage

girls and matching wits with a higher-status 
prosecutor who&#39;s way overconfident for etc,

but lest you think this is just Ace Attorney 
with top hats and Cockney rhyming slang,

they also put Sherlock Holmes in it. Fun fact: 
Sherlock Holmes meets my original character

and they become best friends and solve mysteries 
together is arguably the world&#39;s oldest sub genre

of fan fiction. I&#39;m pretty sure Queen Victoria was 
writing her own version of that whenever she was

demurely fingering herself in a Westminster 
tearoom. And that&#39;s what this is. Only with Doctor

Watson replaced with another underage girl but 
that&#39;s par for the fucking course, isn&#39;t it.

Now, I do like Ace Attorney games, and I fucking 
hate Ace Attorney games. But I like them. But ooh

how I hate them. I love how expressive they are 
in the character design and animation. I like it

when you call out a simpering smugfuck with a face 
like the unbesmirched top on a new jar of peanut

butter and mess it up with your butter knife of 
justice until they&#39;re hopping around banging their

head on things like they just found a lioness 
creeping through their pubes. And with that,

I also love the satisfaction of solving the 
puzzles. As I believe I&#39;ve talked about before,

my one major ask of a detective puzzle 
game is that it should make me feel clever,

and there are plenty of moments in Ace Attorney 
that do that when the accused thief is weirdly

okay with our suggestion that we search his 
pockets for the missing diamond buttplug,

and then I remember that he was caught pinching 
the bums of court officials ten minutes ago and

that we actually need to be searching the 
bailiff&#39;s rectum. But as for why I also hate

Ace Attorney games - OOH I HATE &#39;EM - part of 
it&#39;s the sameyness. I wanna say every fucking

defendant in every game inexplicably hides 
information from you until you can crowbar

it out of them mid-trial. Even when the 
main character&#39;s the defendant, actually.

And afterwards the same conversation always 
ensues. &quot;I&#39;m so sorry that I lied, protagonist,

I expect you want to resign as my lawyer now and 
leave me to be falsely executed.&quot; &quot;No, client,

I will not resign as your lawyer.&quot; &quot;Gwuh? 
But why?&quot; &quot;Because it&#39;s a lawyer&#39;s job to

have faith in their client, and I don&#39;t believe 
lying should carry the death penalty because

I&#39;m just that bloody great.&quot; Which brings me to 
the main reason why I hate Ace Attorney games,

it&#39;s the same reason I hate most visual 
novels, that they never use ten words where

ninety thousand billion will do. Getting to the 
point feels like pulling teeth while you and your

dental patient are riding different escalators. 
&quot;I believe we should search the bailiff&#39;s rectum!&quot;

&quot;Whuh?&quot; &quot;But the bailiff didn&#39;t steal the diamond 
butt plug! Ha ha ha my learned friend has clearly

forgotten who is on trial here, smug smug.&quot; Smash 
hands on desk like a short-tempered DJ who&#39;s just

seen a cockroach. &quot;Not at all!&quot; &quot;Huh?&quot; &quot;I submit 
that it is perfectly possible for the diamond

butt plug to be in the bailiff&#39;s rectum WITHOUT 
them being the one who stole it!&quot; &quot;Whuh?&quot; &quot;But

how?&quot; Jesus Christ, if they&#39;d just let me bend 
the fucker over the witness stand and yank his

trousers down we could all be at lunch by now.
And this hurts the all important making me feel

clever factor because I did feel clever nine 
hundred text boxes ago but now the game&#39;s

dropped so many obvious hints a fucking 
sealion with dropsy could&#39;ve figured it

out. Games like this need more than just a 
fast text option which incidentally doesn&#39;t

even make the text go by THAT much faster but 
that&#39;s a different niggle entirely - it needs a

fucking fast BRAIN option that replaces half the 
dialogue with meaningful eyebrow wiggles. Still,

I suppose it&#39;s all pacing. My favourite parts 
of these games are when you&#39;re nailing a lying

witness to the wall and the cool music&#39;s playing 
and everyone&#39;s reacting like they&#39;re getting

slapped with wet trouts again and again and we&#39;re 
speedily descending the slopes of mount justice

on our truth toboggan, and that wouldn&#39;t be as 
satisfying without a long and arduous climb to

the top of mount justice beforehand. And thinking 
about it since detective games inherently lack

replay value it&#39;s not so bad for the games to be 
formulaic as long as there are new mysteries to

explore. Columbo&#39;s formulaic and I love Columbo. 
That&#39;s what I want out of Ace Attorney - I want to

feel like anime Columbo. But that&#39;ll never work 
&#39;cos the raincoat would cover up his miniskirt.
